Post.title: Hello World
Post._content:
Welcome to [Hexo](https://hexo.io/)! This is your very first post. Check [documentation](https://hexo.io/docs/) for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in [troubleshooting](https://hexo.io/docs/troubleshooting.html) or you can ask me on [GitHub](https://github.com/hexojs/hexo/issues).

## Quick Start

### Create a new post

``` bash
$ hexo new "My New Post"
```

More info: [Writing](https://hexo.io/docs/writing.html)

### Run server

``` bash
$ hexo server
```

More info: [Server](https://hexo.io/docs/server.html)

### Generate static files

``` bash
$ hexo generate
```

More info: [Generating](https://hexo.io/docs/generating.html)

### Deploy to remote sites

``` bash
$ hexo deploy
```

More info: [Deployment](https://hexo.io/docs/deployment.html)

### More Try

``` c++
protected class A : public C{
public:
    int X() {
        return x;
    }
private:
    int x;
}
```


---

____




---

``

1|
:---:|:---:
|dadaa
sdaa|ddddd

$$
F_x = a^2 + b^2
$$

Post.title: Python3 (1)
Post._content:
# Python 

Python [^1][^2]

Python  Guido van Rossum  1989 

## Python (The Zen of Python)

*   Beautiful is better than ugly.
    
*   Explicit is better than implicit.
    
*   Simple is better than complex.
    
*   Complex is better than complicated.
    
*   Flat is better than nested.
    
*   Sparse is better than dense.
    
*   Readability counts.
    
*   Special cases arent special enough to break the rules.
    
*   Although practicality beats purity.
    
*   Errors should never pass silently.
    
*   Unless explicitly silenced.
    
*   In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess. 
     
*   There should be one  and preferably only one  obvious way to do it. 
     
*   Although that way may not be obvious at first unless youre Dutch 
    Dutch,  
*   Now is better than never. 
     
*   Although never is often better than right now. 
     
*   If the implementation is hard to explain, it is a bad idea. 
     
*   If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea. 
     
*   Namespaces are one honking great idea  lets do more of those! 
    

## Python 

* 
* 
* 
* 

# Windows10 

 [Python ](https://www.python.org/)  __Python V3.6.5 for windows__

PATH


|  |  |
|:---:|:---:|
| PATH | "(Python)\\Scripts\\"  "(Python)\\" |
| PYTHONPATH | PYTHONPATHPythonimportPYTHONPATH |
| PYTHONSTARTUP | PythonPYTHONSTARTUP |
| PYTHONCASEOK | PYTHONCASEOK, python. |
| PYTHONHOME | PYTHONSTARTUPPYTHONPATH |

____ `python` PythonPython

python [IntelliJ IDEA](https://www.jetbrains.com/idea/) Python

## Python (The Zen of Python)

*   Beautiful is better than ugly.
    
*   Explicit is better than implicit.
    
*   Simple is better than complex.
    
*   Complex is better than complicated.
    
*   Flat is better than nested.
    
*   Sparse is better than dense.
    
*   Readability counts.
    
*   Special cases arent special enough to break the rules.
    
*   Although practicality beats purity.
    
*   Errors should never pass silently.
    
*   Unless explicitly silenced.
    
*   In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess. 
     
*   There should be one  and preferably only one  obvious way to do it. 
     
*   Although that way may not be obvious at first unless youre Dutch 
    Dutch,  
*   Now is better than never. 
     
*   Although never is often better than right now. 
     
*   If the implementation is hard to explain, it is a bad idea. 
     
*   If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.

Python Guido van Rossum 1989

Python (The Zen of Python)

  • Beautiful is better than ugly.
  • Explicit is better than implicit.
  • Simple is better than complex.
  • Complex is better than complicated.
  • Flat is better than nested.
  • Sparse is better than dense.
  • Readability counts.
  • Special cases arent special enough to break the rules.
  • Although practicality beats purity.
  • Errors should never pass silently.
  • Unless explicitly silenced.
  • In the face of ambiguity, refuse the temptation to guess.
  • There should be one and preferably only one obvious way to do it.
  • Although that way may not be obvious at first unless youre Dutch
    Dutch,
  • Now is better than never.
  • Although never is often better than right now.
  • If the implementation is hard to explain, it is a bad idea.
  • If the implementation is easy to explain, it may be a good idea.
  • Namespaces are one honking great idea lets do more of those!

Post.title: Python3 (3)
Post._content:
# 

Python 


=
=,=

```python
answer = 42 #
```
# 

## (Number)

### (int)

Python3int C/C++  int longpython160x80o

### (float)

1.23x10912.3x108

### (bool)

TrueFalseTrueFalse
True1False0

andornot

### (complex)



```python
s = 3 + 1j
d = complex(3,2)
```
### 

python  Python

```python
5/2 #  2.5
5//2 #  20
5%2 # /
2**5 #
```
## (String)

\'\"\'abc\'\"xyz\"\'\'\"\"\'abc\'abc3
[:]

```python
print  (str[0:-1])  #   
print  (str[0])  #   
print  (str[2:5])  #   
print  (str[2:])  #   
print  (str * 2)  #   
print  (str + "TEST")  # 
```
python()javaTrue

## (List)





## (Tuple)


tuplelist
 0  1 

```python
tup1 =  ()  # 
tup2 =  (20,)  # 
```
stringlisttuplesequence

## (Set)


 { }  set() 
 set()  { } { } 

```python
a = set('abracadabra') 
b = set('alacazam') 
print(a) 
print(a - b)  # ab  
print(a | b)  # ab  
print(a & b)  # ab  
print(a ^ b)  # ab
```
## (Dictionary)



"{ }"(key) : (value)
(key)(key)
keyvalue.keys()  .value() 

## (None)

None00

# 

## del var

del

```python
del var1,var2,var3
```

## int(x[,base])

```python
age = int(10.9) # xint0
status = int('10',2) # 2102'10'
```
## float(x)

```
weight = float(50) # xfloat
```

## complex(real[,imag])

```
a = complex(1) #  1 + 0j
b = complex(-1,5) #  -1 
```
## str(x)

x

## repr(x)



## eval(expression[, globals[, locals]])



|  |  |
|---|---|
| expression |  |
| globals |  |
| locals |  |

```python
eval('2 + 2') # 4int
n = 4
eval('n ** 2') # 16int
eval('"hello," + str(0)') # 'hello,0'string
```
## tuple(s)

s

## list(s)

s

## dict(d)

d

```
sex = dict(boy='1',girl='0') #
week = dict([('Mon', 0), ('Tues', 1), ('Wed', 2), 
             ('Thur', 3), ('Fri', 4), ('Sat', 5), ('Sun', 6)]) #
```
## frozenset([iterable])

iterable
iterable
()

```python
tup = (3, 5.0, "test", (2, 2), ([2,3],[3,3])) #intfloatstringtuplelisttuple
list = [321,"test",((2,2),(3,3))] #intstringtupletuple
frozenset(tup) # list
frozenset(list) # list
```
## chr(x) ord(c)

chr(x) xASCII
ord(c) cASCII

## hex(x) oct(x)

hex(x) x16
oct(x) x8

## id(x)

x

## type(var)



## isinstance(var, type)

typeTrueFalse

```python
n = 3
if isinstance(n, int) :
   print("n's type is int)
```
type()isinstance()
ABA
type()AB
isinstance()BA
